senses.definition: to leave somebody, especially somebody you are responsible for, with no intention of returning

examples.en: The baby had been abandoned by its mother.
People often simply abandon their pets when they go abroad.
‘We have been abandoned to our fate,’ said one resident.
The study showed a deep fear among the elderly of being abandoned to the care of strangers.

senses.definition: to leave a thing or place, especially because it is impossible or dangerous to stay

examples.en: Snow forced many drivers to abandon their vehicles.
He gave the order to abandon ship (= to leave the ship because it was sinking).
They had to abandon their lands to the invading forces.

senses.definition: to stop doing something, especially before it is finished; to stop having something

examples.en: They abandoned the match because of rain.
The plans for reform were quietly abandoned.
She abandoned hope of any reconciliation.
We had to abandon any further attempt at negotiation.

senses.definition: to stop supporting or helping somebody; to stop believing in something

examples.en: The country abandoned its political leaders after the war.
Critics accused him of abandoning his principles.
This principle has now been effectively abandoned.

senses.definition: to feel an emotion so strongly that you can feel nothing else

examples.en: He abandoned himself to despair.

senses.definition: a way of behaving that is not sensible and shows that you do not care about the possible results of your actions or what other people think

examples.en: He spent money with careless abandon.

senses.definition: without thinking about the results or effects of a particular action
the fact that somebody/something is able to do something

examples.en: People with the disease may lose their ability to communicate.
This program has the ability to adapt to its user.
Students must demonstrate the ability to understand simple texts.
She has an uncanny ability to predict what consumers will want.
A gentle form of exercise will increase your ability to relax.

senses.definition: a level of skill or intelligence

examples.en: Their athletic ability is stunning.
cognitive/intellectual/mental ability
A woman of her ability will easily find a job.
Are you used to teaching students of mixed abilities?
It's important to discover the natural abilities of each child.
I try to do my job to the best of my ability (= as well as I can).

senses.definition: the quality of being able to be or having to be

examples.en: capability

senses.definition: the fact of having the quality mentioned

examples.en: changeability

senses.definition: having the skill, intelligence, opportunity, etc. needed to do something

examples.en: You must be able to speak French for this job.
A viral illness left her barely able to walk.
We're still able to get visas to come and go from Thailand.
I didn't feel able to disagree with him.
Will you be able to come?
Are you really willing and able to do what is necessary?
They don't even seem able to see what's good about their ideas.
These families are less able to afford a balanced, healthy diet.

senses.definition: intelligent; good at something

examples.en: She's the ablest student in the class.

senses.definition: that can or must be

examples.en: calculable
taxable

senses.definition: having the quality of

examples.en: fashionable
comfortable
changeable

senses.definition: to officially end a law, a system or an institution

examples.en: This tax should be abolished.

senses.definition: the deliberate ending of a pregnancy at an early stage

examples.en: to support/oppose abortion
a woman’s right to abortion
the country's strict abortion laws
Both pro-choice and anti-abortion groups want to ensure their voices are heard.

senses.definition: a medical operation to end a pregnancy at an early stage

examples.en: She decided to have an abortion.
Some medical staff wanted the right to refuse to perform abortions.

senses.definition: the process of giving birth to a baby before it is fully developed and able to survive
on the subject of somebody/something; in connection with somebody/something

examples.en: a book about flowers
Tell me all about it.
What's she so angry about?
There's something strange about him.
There's something about this business that is not quite right.
I don't know what you're on about (= talking about).
There's nothing you can do about it now.

senses.definition: used to describe the purpose or an aspect of something

examples.en: Movies are all about making money these days.
What was all that about? (= what was the reason for what has just happened?)

senses.definition: busy with something; doing something

examples.en: Everywhere people were going about their daily business.
And while you’re about it… (= while you’re doing that)

senses.definition: in many directions in a place; here and there

examples.en: We wandered about the town for an hour or so.
He looked about the room.

senses.definition: in various parts of a place; here and there

examples.en: The papers were strewn about the room.

senses.definition: next to a place or person; in the area mentioned

examples.en: She's somewhere about the office.

senses.definition: surrounding somebody/something

examples.en: She wore a shawl about her shoulders.

senses.definition: used when asking for information about somebody/something

examples.en: How about Ruth? Have you heard from her?
I'm having fish. What about you?

senses.definition: used to make a suggestion

examples.en: How about going for a walk?
How about we go for a walk?
What about a break?

senses.definition: a little more or less than; a little before or after

examples.en: It costs about $10.
They waited (for) about an hour.
He arrived (at) about ten.

senses.definition: nearly; very close to

examples.en: I'm just about ready.
This is about the best we can hope for.

senses.definition: in many directions; here and there

examples.en: The children were rushing about in the garden.

senses.definition: in no particular order; in various places

examples.en: Her books were lying about on the floor.

senses.definition: doing nothing in particular

examples.en: People were standing about in the road.

senses.definition: able to be found in a place

examples.en: There was nobody about.
There's a lot of flu about.
She’s somewhere about—I saw her a few minutes ago.

senses.definition: facing the opposite direction

examples.en: He brought the ship about.

senses.definition: almost; very nearly

examples.en: I've met just about everyone.
‘Did you reach your sales target?’ ‘Just about.’

senses.definition: approximately

examples.en: She should be arriving just about now.

senses.definition: able to go outside again after an illness
travelling around a place

examples.en: We've been out and about talking to people all over the country.

idioms.word: that’s about all | that’s about it

senses.definition: used to say that you have finished telling somebody about something and there is nothing to add

examples.en: ‘Anything else?’ ‘No, that's about it for now.’

senses.definition: to be close to doing something; to be going to do something very soon

examples.en: I was just about to ask you the same thing.

idioms.word: be not about to do something

senses.definition: to not be willing to do something; to not intend to do something

examples.en: I've never done any cooking and I'm not about to start now.

senses.definition: at or to a higher place or position than something/somebody

examples.en: The water came above our knees.
We were flying above the clouds.
the people in the apartment above mine
A captain in the navy ranks above a captain in the army.
They finished the year six places above their local rivals.

senses.definition: more than something; greater in number, level or age than somebody/something

examples.en: Inflation is above 6%.
Temperatures have been above average.
We cannot accept children above the age of 10.

senses.definition: of greater importance or of higher quality than somebody/something

examples.en: I rate her above most other players of her age.

senses.definition: too good or too honest to do something

examples.en: She's not above lying when it suits her.
He's above suspicion (= he is completely trusted).

senses.definition: louder or clearer than another sound

examples.en: I couldn't hear her above the noise of the traffic.

senses.definition: most important of all; especially

examples.en: Above all, keep in touch.

senses.definition: having too high an opinion of yourself
in addition to something

examples.en: There are other factors over and above those we have discussed.

senses.definition: at or to a higher place

examples.en: Put it on the shelf above.
Seen from above the cars looked tiny.
I could hear somebody calling out my name from up above.
They were acting on instructions from above (= from somebody in a higher position of authority).

senses.definition: greater in number, level or age

examples.en: increases of 5% and above
A score of 70 or above will get you an ‘A’.
children aged 12 and above

senses.definition: earlier in something written or printed

examples.en: As was stated above…
See above, page 97.
My client is the mother of the two above-named children.

senses.definition: (to do) even more than is expected or demanded
see_alsos: (above and) beyond the call of duty

examples.en: Our staff members will go above and beyond to ensure that our customers are satisfied.

senses.definition: mentioned or printed previously in a letter, book, etc.

examples.en: Please write to us at the above address.

senses.definition: in or to a foreign country

examples.en: to go/travel/live/study abroad
She worked abroad for a year.
imports of cheap food from abroad
He was famous, both at home and abroad (= in his own country and in other countries).
For a holiday abroad you need a valid passport.

senses.definition: being talked about or felt by many people

examples.en: There was news abroad that a change was coming.

senses.definition: outside; outdoors
the fact of somebody being away from a place where they are usually expected to be; the occasion or period of time when somebody is away

examples.en: The decision was made in my absence (= while I was not there).
We did not receive any news during his long absence.
absence from work
repeated absences from school

senses.definition: the fact of somebody/something not existing or not being available; a lack of something

examples.en: I was surprised by the absence of any women on the board of directors.
The case was dismissed in the absence of any definite proof.

idioms.word: absence makes the heart grow fonder

senses.definition: used to say that when you are away from somebody that you love, you love them even more
not present in a situation or place, when it is obvious that you should be there

examples.en: The meeting went well but Nigel was conspicuous by his absence.

senses.definition: not in a place because of illness, etc.

examples.en: She was absent from work for two weeks.
Local people were conspicuously absent from the meeting.

senses.definition: not present in something

examples.en: Love was totally absent from his childhood.
She now played with a passion that had been strangely absent from her previous performance.

senses.definition: showing that you are not really looking at or thinking about what is happening around you

examples.en: an absent expression

senses.definition: to not go to or be in a place where you are expected to be

examples.en: He had absented himself from the office for the day.

senses.definition: without

examples.en: Absent further evidence, the police had no choice but to release him without charge.

senses.definition: total and complete

examples.en: I've joined a class for absolute beginners.
absolute confidence/trust/silence/truth
‘You're wrong,’ she said with absolute certainty.
Clean water is an absolute necessity.
Around them the darkness was absolute, the silence oppressive.

senses.definition: used, especially in spoken English, to give emphasis to what you are saying

examples.en: We must keep costs to an absolute minimum.
This room is an absolute disgrace.
They're talking absolute nonsense.
He must earn an absolute fortune.

senses.definition: definite and without any doubt

examples.en: There was no absolute proof.
He taught us that the laws of physics were absolute.
The story offers no clear message, no absolute truth.

senses.definition: (of a legal decision) final

examples.en: The divorce became absolute last week.

senses.definition: not limited in any way

examples.en: absolute power/authority
an absolute ruler/monarchy (= one with no limit to their power)

senses.definition: existing or measured independently and not in relation to something else

examples.en: Although prices are falling in absolute terms, energy is still expensive.
Beauty cannot be measured by any absolute standard.

senses.definition: an idea or a principle that is believed to be true or relevant in any circumstances

examples.en: Right and wrong are, for her, moral absolutes.

senses.definition: used to emphasize that something is completely true

examples.en: You're absolutely right.
He made it absolutely clear.
I'm not absolutely certain I posted it.
Are you absolutely sure?
Training is absolutely essential in this business.
Don't delay for longer than absolutely necessary.
The place was absolutely packed.
It was absolutely pouring with rain.

variants.html: absolutely no…, absolutely nothing

senses.definition: used to emphasize something negative

examples.en: That man does absolutely no work!
There's absolutely nothing more the doctors can do.

senses.definition: used with adjectives or verbs that express strong feelings or extreme qualities to mean ‘extremely’

examples.en: absolutely delighted/thrilled
We were absolutely devastated at the news.
I absolutely love strawberries.
She absolutely adores you.
absolutely fantastic/amazing
He's an absolutely brilliant cook.

senses.definition: used to emphasize that you agree with somebody, or to give somebody permission to do something

examples.en: ‘They could have told us, couldn't they?’ ‘Absolutely!’
‘Can we leave a little early?’ ‘Absolutely!’

senses.definition: used to emphasize that you strongly disagree with somebody, or to refuse permission

examples.en: ‘Was it any good?’ ‘No, absolutely not.’
‘Can I stay up late?’ ‘Absolutely not!’

senses.definition: not considered in relation to other things

examples.en: White-collar crime increased both absolutely and in comparison with other categories.

senses.definition: to take in a liquid, gas or other substance from the surface or space around

examples.en: Plants absorb carbon dioxide from the air.
Let the rice cook until it has absorbed all the water.
The cream is easily absorbed into the skin.

senses.definition: to take in and keep heat, light, energy, sound, etc. instead of reflecting it

examples.en: Black walls absorb a lot of heat during the day.

senses.definition: to reduce the effect of a physical impact or movement

examples.en: This tennis racket absorbs shock on impact.
The bats have graphite shafts that absorb the vibration.

senses.definition: to take something into the mind and learn or understand it

examples.en: It's a lot of information to absorb all at once.
It took me several days to absorb the fact of her death.
They spent a week in Paris just absorbing the atmosphere.

senses.definition: to interest somebody very much so that they pay no attention to anything else

examples.en: This work had absorbed him for several years.
Her work absorbed her completely.

senses.definition: to make something smaller become part of something larger

examples.en: The town absorbs an influx of tourists every summer.
The surrounding small towns have been absorbed into the city.
These committees were gradually absorbed into the local government machine.

senses.definition: to use up a large supply of something, especially money or time

examples.en: The new proposals would absorb $80 billion of the federal budget.
My work absorbs a great deal of my time.

senses.definition: to deal with changes, effects, costs, etc.

examples.en: The company is unable to absorb such huge losses.

senses.definition: based on general ideas and not on any particular real person, thing or situation

examples.en: abstract knowledge/principles
The research shows that pre-school children are capable of thinking in abstract terms.

senses.definition: existing in thought or as an idea but not having a physical reality

examples.en: We may talk of beautiful things but beauty itself is abstract.

senses.definition: not representing people or things in a realistic way, but expressing the artist’s ideas about them

examples.en: the work of American abstract expressionists like Mark Rothko

senses.definition: an abstract work of art

examples.en: Kandinsky’s first pure abstracts are marked by their wild colour.

senses.definition: a short piece of writing containing the main ideas in a document

examples.en: Abstracts of about 300 words should be submitted to the conference committee who will decide which papers to accept.
This information is supplementary to the abstract of accounts.

senses.definition: in a general way, without referring to a particular real person, thing or situation

examples.en: Legal questions rarely exist in the abstract; they are based on real cases.
I’m just talking in the abstract now.

senses.definition: to remove something from somewhere

examples.en: She abstracted the main points from the argument.
Their plan is to abstract 8 million gallons of water from the river.

senses.definition: to make a written summary of a book, etc.
extremely silly; not logical and sensible

examples.en: That uniform makes the guards look absurd.
Of course it's not true, what an absurd idea.

senses.definition: things that are or that seem to be absurd

examples.en: He has a good sense of the absurd.

senses.definition: a large quantity that is more than enough

examples.en: The brochure promised beautiful walks with an abundance of wildlife.
The country has an abundance of natural resources.
We were amazed by the sheer abundance of food.

senses.definition: in large quantities

examples.en: Fruit and vegetables grew in abundance on the island.
Exotic plants grew there in great abundance.

senses.definition: the use of something in a way that is wrong or harmful

examples.en: alcohol/drug abuse
The system of paying cash bonuses is open to abuse (= might be used in the wrong way).
The legal system is open to abuse.
He was arrested on charges of corruption and abuse of power.
What she did was an abuse of her position as manager.

senses.definition: unfair, cruel or violent treatment of somebody

examples.en: child abuse
sexual abuse
reported abuses by the secret police
They suffered years of physical abuse.

senses.definition: rude and offensive remarks, usually made when somebody is very angry

examples.en: to scream/hurl/shout abuse
a stream/torrent of abuse
The man burst into a torrent of foul-mouthed racist abuse.

senses.definition: to make bad use of something, or to use so much of something that it harms your health

examples.en: to abuse alcohol/drugs
He systematically abused his body with heroin and cocaine.
People who abuse alcohol over a long period will develop health problems.

senses.definition: to use power or knowledge unfairly or wrongly

examples.en: She abused her position as principal by giving jobs to her friends.
He felt they had abused his trust by talking about him to the press (= tricked him, although he had trusted them).

senses.definition: to treat a person or an animal in a cruel or violent way, especially sexually

examples.en: The boy had been sexually abused.
All the children had been physically and emotionally abused.
abused children

senses.definition: to make rude or offensive remarks to or about somebody

examples.en: The referee had been threatened and verbally abused.
He claimed he had been racially abused.

senses.definition: connected with education, especially studying in schools and universities

examples.en: high/low academic standards
She had a brilliant academic career.
one of this country's most prestigious academic institutions
improving the academic achievement of all students
The university is renowned throughout the world for its academic excellence.
academic research/researchers
We are deeply committed to safeguarding academic freedom.

senses.definition: involving a lot of reading and studying rather than practical or technical skills

examples.en: a mixture of vocational and academic courses
people whose skills are practical rather than academic
academic qualifications/subjects

senses.definition: good at subjects involving a lot of reading and studying

examples.en: She wasn't very academic and hated school.

senses.definition: not connected to a real or practical situation and therefore not important

examples.en: It's a purely academic question.
The whole thing's academic now—we can't win anyway.
Most of his questions were of an academic nature.

senses.definition: a person who teaches and/or does research at a university or college

examples.en: a leading/distinguished/prominent academic
There is much debate among academics about this issue.

senses.definition: a school or college for special training

examples.en: She trained at the Royal Academy of Music.
a police/military academy

senses.definition: a type of official organization that aims to encourage and develop art, literature, science, etc.

examples.en: the Royal Academy of Arts

senses.definition: a secondary school in Scotland

examples.en: He went to Ayr Academy.

senses.definition: a private school in the US
a school in England that is independent of local authority control
to happen faster or earlier; to make something happen faster or earlier

examples.en: Inflation continues to accelerate.
Exposure to the sun can accelerate the ageing process.

senses.definition: to start to go faster

examples.en: The runners accelerated smoothly around the bend.
The car accelerated to overtake me.
The car purred into life and accelerated away.

senses.definition: a way of pronouncing the words of a language that shows which country, area or social class a person comes from; how well somebody pronounces a particular language

examples.en: a northern/Dublin/Scottish accent
a strong/broad accent (= one that is easy to notice)
She spoke English with an accent.
The Americans had learned Korean and spoke with a good accent.

senses.definition: the emphasis that you should give to part of a word when saying it

examples.en: In ‘today’ the accent is on the second syllable.

senses.definition: a mark on a letter to show that it should be pronounced in a particular way

examples.en: Canapé has an accent on the ‘e’.

senses.definition: a special importance that is given to something

examples.en: In all our products the accent is on quality.

senses.definition: to emphasize a part of something

examples.en: The women accent their eyes with make-up.

senses.definition: to take willingly something that is offered; to say ‘yes’ to an offer, invitation, etc.

examples.en: He asked me to marry him and I accepted.
Please accept our sincere apologies.
It was pouring with rain so I accepted his offer of a lift.
I am unfortunately unable to accept your kind invitation.
The board of directors accepted our proposal.
She's decided not to accept the job.
Please accept this small token of my appreciation.
He is charged with accepting bribes from a firm of suppliers.
She said she'd accept $15 for it.

senses.definition: to agree to or approve of something

examples.en: They accepted the court's decision.
The judge refused to accept his evidence.
He accepted all the changes we proposed.
Are you willing to accept the challenge?
She won't accept advice from anyone.
My article has been accepted for publication.

senses.definition: to take payment in a particular form

examples.en: This machine only accepts coins.
Credit cards are widely accepted.

senses.definition: to admit that you are responsible or to blame for something

examples.en: He accepts full responsibility for what happened.
You have to accept the consequences of your actions.

senses.definition: to continue in a difficult situation without complaining, because you realize that you cannot change it

examples.en: You just have to accept the fact that we're never going to be rich.
to be willing/prepared to accept something
Nothing will change as long as the workers continue to accept these appalling conditions.
They accept the risks as part of the job.
He just refused to accept that his father was no longer there.

senses.definition: to make somebody feel welcome and part of a group

examples.en: It may take years to be completely accepted by the local community.
She had never been accepted into what was essentially a man's world.
He never really accepted her as his own child.

senses.definition: to believe that something is true

examples.en: I don't accept his version of events.
Can we accept his account as the true version?
I accept that this will not be popular.
I am not prepared to accept that this decision is final.
It is generally accepted that people are motivated by success.

examples.cf: something is accepted to be, have, etc. something
examples.en: Their workforce is widely accepted to have the best conditions in Europe.

senses.definition: to allow somebody to join an organization, attend an institution, use a service, etc.

examples.en: The college he applied to has accepted him.
She was disappointed not to be accepted into the club.
The landlord was willing to accept us as tenants.
She was accepted to study music.

senses.definition: agreed or approved of by most people in a society

examples.en: Children must learn socially acceptable behaviour.
It is perfectly acceptable for you as an employee to say no.

senses.definition: that somebody agrees is of a good enough standard or allowed

examples.en: For this course a pass in English at grade B is acceptable.
Air pollution in the city had reached four times the acceptable levels.
We want a political solution that is acceptable to all parties.
It is possible to find a solution that is acceptable to both sides.

senses.definition: not very good but good enough

examples.en: The food was acceptable, but no more.
Inspectors found that teaching standards were acceptable, but could be improved.

senses.definition: the act of accepting a gift, an invitation, an offer, etc.

examples.en: Please confirm your acceptance of this offer in writing.
He made a short acceptance speech/speech of acceptance.
Invitations have been sent out and 80 acceptances have already been received.
So far we have had one refusal and three acceptances.

senses.definition: the act of agreeing with something and approving of it

examples.en: The new laws have gained widespread acceptance.

senses.definition: the process of allowing somebody to join something or be a member of a group

examples.en: Your acceptance into the insurance plan is guaranteed.
Social acceptance is important for most young people.
The group is now seeking formal acceptance.

senses.definition: the quality of being willing to accept an unpleasant or difficult situation

examples.en: acceptance of death/suffering

senses.definition: the opportunity or right to use something or to see somebody/something

examples.en: High-speed internet access has become a necessity.
You need a password to get access to the computer system.
access to information/services/resources
access to healthcare/education
They are seeking increased access to markets overseas.
to provide/allow access to something/somebody
to restrict/block access to something/somebody
Journalists were denied access to the President.
Many divorced fathers only have access to their children at weekends (= they are allowed by law to see them only at weekends).

senses.definition: a way of entering or reaching a place

examples.en: The police gained access through a broken window.
Many paths have become overgrown, blocking access.
There is easy access by road.
We welcome disabled visitors and there is wheelchair access to all parts of the park.
The only access to the farmhouse is across the fields.

senses.definition: to open a computer file or use a computer system

examples.en: Most people use their phones to access the internet.
to access a file/database
It has never been easier to access information.
All employees can access real-time data.
You should regularly change the password you use to access your online accounts.
Their website can be accessed via the link below.

senses.definition: to be able to have or use something, especially something that you have a right to

examples.en: Being informed is the first step towards accessing better health services.
States need to understand how to access the federal resources that are available.
Businesses often provide their products at a discount in order to access a potential market.

senses.definition: to reach, enter or use something

examples.en: The loft can be accessed by a ladder.
The balcony is accessed via French doors from the living room.

senses.definition: that can be reached, entered, used, seen, etc.

examples.en: The remote desert area is accessible only by helicopter.
These documents are not accessible to the public.

senses.definition: that can be reached, entered, used, etc. by somebody who has problems walking

examples.en: accessible toilets for wheelchair users
The beach should be accessible to everyone.

senses.definition: easy to understand

examples.en: Her poetry is always very accessible.
a programme making science more accessible to young people

senses.definition: easy to talk to and to get to know
an unpleasant event, especially in a vehicle, that happens unexpectedly and causes injury or damage

examples.en: a car/road/traffic accident
He was killed in an accident.
One in seven accidents is caused by sleepy drivers.
The accident happened at 3 p.m.
to have an accident
a serious/minor accident
a fatal accident (= in which somebody is killed)
Every year in the United Kingdom more than 4 000 people die in accidents in the home.
a climbing/riding accident
Take out accident insurance before you go on your trip.
I didn't mean to break it—it was an accident.
Their boat sank in a freak accident.
His son died in a tragic cycling accident.
There are a number of accident blackspots (= places where lots of accidents happen) on that road.
We don't know the cause of the accident.
She was badly injured in a motorcycle accident.

senses.definition: something that happens by chance and without an obvious cause

examples.en: Their early arrival was just an accident.
It is no accident that lawn tennis was invented in England.
an accident of birth/fate/history (= describing facts and events that are due to chance or circumstances)

idioms.word: an accident/a disaster waiting to happen

senses.definition: a thing or person that is very likely to cause danger or a problem in the future because of the condition it is in or the way they behave

examples.en: Any one of these nuclear plants may be a disaster waiting to happen.

senses.definition: people say accidents will happen to tell somebody who has had an accident, for example breaking something, that it does not matter and they should not worry
in a way that is not planned or organized

examples.en: We met by accident at the airport.
Helen got into acting purely by accident.
It happened, whether by accident or design, that Steve and I were the last two people to leave.

senses.definition: a series of unpleasant events caused by bad luck

examples.en: The whole affair has been a chapter of accidents from start to finish.

senses.definition: by chance; in a way that was not planned

examples.en: As I turned around, I accidentally hit him in the face.
The damage couldn't have been caused accidentally.

senses.definition: to provide somebody with a room or place to sleep, live or sit

examples.en: The hotel can accommodate up to 500 guests.
The aircraft is capable of accommodating 28 passengers.

senses.definition: to provide enough space for somebody/something

examples.en: The garage can accommodate three cars.
The old town hall now accommodates a Folk Museum.

senses.definition: to consider something such as somebody’s opinion or a fact and be influenced by it when you are deciding what to do or explaining something

examples.en: Our proposal tries to accommodate the special needs of minority groups.
She modified her views so as to accommodate the objections of American feminists.

senses.definition: to help somebody by doing what they want

examples.en: I have accommodated the press a great deal, giving numerous interviews.
I’m sure the bank will be able to accommodate you.

senses.definition: to change your behaviour so that you can deal with a new situation better

examples.en: I needed to accommodate to the new schedule.

senses.definition: a place to live, work or stay in

examples.en: rented/temporary accommodation
Hotel accommodation is included in the price of your holiday.
We may have to provide alternative accommodation for you.
First-class accommodation is available on all flights.

senses.definition: used to emphasize something that is real or exists in fact

senses.definition: to let people know that something is going to happen, or that a job is available by giving details about it in a newspaper, on a notice in a public place, on the internet, etc.

examples.en: Sellers pay upfront to advertise.

The best jobs are not always advertised in newspapers.
Vacancies are usually advertised on our website.
We advertised the concert quite widely.

senses.definition: to show or tell something about yourself to other people

examples.en: I wouldn't advertise the fact that you don't have a work permit.
She coughed to advertise her presence.

senses.definition: a notice, picture or film telling people about a product, job or service

examples.en: a newspaper/television advertisement
an online advertisement
You can place an advertisement on a classifieds website.
Television and radio refused to carry advertisements for the album.

variants.html: (British English also advert)

senses.definition: an example of something that shows its good qualities

examples.en: Dirty streets and homelessness are no advertisement for a prosperous society.
He's a walking advertisement for healthy living.

senses.definition: the act of advertising something and making it public

examples.en: We are employing an assistant to help with the advertisement of the group’s activities.

senses.definition: the activity and industry of advertising things to people on television, in newspapers, on the internet, etc.

examples.en: Cigarette advertising has been banned.
radio/TV/online advertising
Paid advertising on social media is an assured way to reach out to customers.
The company's print and digital advertising rose compared with the same period a year ago.
a career in advertising
Val works for an advertising agency (= a company that designs advertisements).
A good advertising campaign will increase our sales.
She is a successful advertising executive.
We were very happy with our advertising strategy last year.

senses.definition: an opinion or a suggestion about what somebody should do in a particular situation

examples.en: expert/practical/professional/medical advice
We were advised to seek legal advice.
The service offers information and advice on possible careers.
Ask your teacher's advice on how to prepare for the exam.
Ask your teacher for advice on how to prepare for the exam.
They give good advice to parents about managing difficult behaviour.
We were advised to seek advice from an expert.
Let me give you a piece of advice.
A word of advice. Don't wear that dress.
Take my advice. Don't do it.
Follow your doctor's advice.
I went there on the advice of a friend.
I chose it on his advice.
She went back to work against the advice of her doctor (= her doctor advised her not to).
The centre offers a free and confidential advice service.

senses.definition: to tell somebody what you think they should do in a particular situation

examples.en: I would strongly advise against going out on your own.
They advised me against visiting the troubled south of the country.
The Foreign Office is advising Britons against all non-essential travel to the region.
They advised against the use of military force.
Her mother was away and couldn't advise her.
I'd advise extreme caution.
‘Get there early,’ she advised (them).
Police are advising people to stay at home.
Doctors advised the patient to have surgery.
I'd advise you not to tell him.
Solicitors advised their clients to contact their local councillors.
They advise that a passport be carried with you at all times.
They advise that a passport should be carried with you at all times.
It is strongly advised that you take out insurance.
I'd advise buying your tickets well in advance if you want to travel in August.

senses.definition: to give somebody help and information on a subject that you know a lot about

examples.en: We employ an expert to advise on new technology.
The nurse will advise about getting out of bed, bathing, and diet.
She advises the government on environmental issues.
They can advise customers about safely using and storing pesticides.
The pharmacist will advise which medicines are safe to take.

examples.cf: advise somebody what, which, whether, etc…
examples.en: Your lawyer can advise you whether to take any action.

senses.definition: to officially tell somebody something

examples.en: Please advise us of any change of address.
to advise somebody of their rights/the situation
You will be advised of the outcome of your application.
Please keep me advised of new developments in this case.

examples.cf: advise somebody when, where, how, etc…
examples.en: I will contact you later to advise you when to come.
I regret to advise you that the course is now full.

senses.definition: a person who supports or speaks in favour of somebody or of a public plan or action

examples.en: an advocate for hospital workers
a staunch advocate of free speech

senses.definition: a person who defends somebody in court

examples.en: Solicitors often appear as advocates in the lower courts.
Those charged should be represented by trained, qualified legal advocates.

senses.definition: (in Scotland and South Africa) a lawyer who has the right to argue cases in higher courts
to support something publicly

examples.en: The group does not advocate the use of violence.
Heart specialists strongly advocate low-cholesterol diets.
These policies have been widely advocated.
Many experts advocate rewarding your child for good behaviour.
The report advocated that all buildings be fitted with smoke detectors.
The report advocated that all buildings should be fitted with smoke detectors.

variants.html: (North American English also esthetic)

senses.definition: connected with beauty and art and the understanding of beautiful things

examples.en: the aesthetic appeal of the songs
an aesthetic appreciation of the landscape
The works of art are judged on purely aesthetic grounds.
The benefits of conservation are both financial and aesthetic.

senses.definition: made in an artistic way and beautiful to look at

examples.en: Their furniture was more aesthetic than functional.

variants.html: (North American English also esthetic)

senses.definition: the qualities and ideas in a work of art or literature that relate to beauty and the nature of art

examples.en: The students debated the aesthetic of the poems.

senses.definition: the branch of philosophy that studies the principles of beauty, especially in art
events that are of public interest or political importance

examples.en: world/international affairs
an expert on foreign affairs (= political events in other countries)
We are expecting a statement from the home affairs (= political events in your own country) spokesman.
internal/external affairs
affairs of state

senses.definition: an event that people are talking about or describing in a particular way

examples.en: The newspapers exaggerated the whole affair wildly.
She wanted the celebration to be a simple family affair.
Many people have criticized the way the government handled the affair.
The Whitewater affair was the biggest scandal of the decade.

senses.definition: a sexual relationship between two people, usually when one or both of them are already in a relationship with somebody else

examples.en: She was having an affair with a co-worker.
an extramarital affair
It's the story of a secret affair between a married teacher and her teenage student.

senses.definition: matters connected with a person’s private business and financial situation

examples.en: She manages the family's financial affairs.
I looked after my father's financial affairs.
She wanted to put her affairs in order before she died.

senses.definition: a thing that somebody is responsible for (and that other people should not be interested in)

examples.en: How I spend my money is my affair.

senses.definition: an object that is unusual or difficult to describe

examples.en: Her hat was an amazing affair with feathers and a huge brim.

senses.definition: a situation

examples.en: This state of affairs can no longer be ignored.

senses.definition: to produce a change in somebody/something

examples.en: How will these changes affect us?
The article deals with issues affecting the lives of children.
Thousands of people have been adversely affected (= affected in a negative way) by the decision.
The quality and health of the soil directly affects the quality and health of the plants.
Your opinion will not affect my decision.
The south of the country was worst affected by the drought.

senses.definition: to attack somebody or a part of the body; to make somebody become ill

examples.en: The disease is more likely to affect women than men.
The condition affects one in five women.
Rub the cream into the affected areas.

senses.definition: to make somebody feel very sad, sorry, etc. about somebody/something

examples.en: They were deeply affected by the news of her death.
Her death affected him deeply.
Try not to let his problems affect you too much.

senses.definition: to pretend to be feeling or thinking something

examples.en: She affected a calmness she did not feel.
We are fascinated by the rich and powerful but often affect to despise them.

senses.definition: to use or wear something that is intended to impress other people

examples.en: I wish he wouldn't affect that ridiculous accent.

senses.definition: the feeling of liking or loving somebody/something very much and caring about them

examples.en: Children need lots of love and affection.
He didn't show his wife any affection.
She was held in deep affection by all her students.
Mr Darcy’s affection for his sister
I have a great affection for New York.

senses.definition: a person’s feelings of love

examples.en: Anne had two men trying to win her affections.
The object of her affections was a young man named Paul.

senses.definition: to have enough money to be able to buy or do something

examples.en: Can we afford a new car?
None of them could afford £50 for a ticket.
I’d give up work if I could afford it.
We can't afford to go abroad this summer.
She never took a taxi, even though she could afford to.
She can well afford to pay for herself.
They couldn't afford to buy a house there.
We can't afford to have children.
He couldn't afford the money to go on the trip.

senses.definition: if you say that you can’t afford to do something, you mean that you should not do it because it will cause problems for you if you do

examples.en: We cannot afford to ignore this warning.
They could ill afford to lose any more staff.
The people who suffer most are those who can least afford to lose.
We simply can't afford to take any risks.
She felt she couldn't afford any more time off work.
We cannot afford any more delays.

senses.definition: to provide somebody with something

examples.en: The tree affords some shelter from the sun.
The legislation aims to afford protection to employees.
Being a college professor affords you the opportunity simply to write and do research.
The programme affords young people the chance to gain work experience.

senses.definition: cheap enough that people can afford to pay it or buy it

examples.en: We offer quality products at affordable prices.
There is a lack of affordable housing in the city.
This model is relatively affordable at just $85.

senses.definition: feeling fear; frightened because you think that you might be hurt or suffer

examples.en: Don't be afraid.
It's all over. There's nothing to be afraid of now.
He had always been afraid of dogs.
They know I'm afraid of heights.
Are you afraid of spiders?
I started to feel afraid of going out alone at night.
The children were afraid to open the door.

senses.definition: worried about what might happen

examples.en: She was afraid of upsetting her parents.
He was afraid of making a fool of himself.
Don't be afraid to ask if you don't understand.
She certainly isn't afraid to speak her mind.
We were afraid (that) we were going to capsize the boat.

senses.definition: worried or frightened that something unpleasant, dangerous, etc. will happen to a particular person or thing

examples.en: I'm not afraid for me, but for the baby.
They had already fired three people and he was afraid for his job.
I am very afraid for their safety.
I was afraid for my life.

senses.definition: used as a polite way of telling somebody something that is unpleasant or disappointing, or that you are sorry about

examples.en: I can't help you, I'm afraid.
I'm afraid we can't come.
I'm afraid that it's not finished yet.
He's no better, I'm afraid to say.
‘Is there any left?’ ‘I'm afraid not.’
‘Will it hurt?’ ‘I'm afraid so.’

senses.definition: later than something; following something in time

examples.en: We'll leave after lunch.
They arrived shortly after 5.
Not long after that he resigned.
Let’s meet the day after tomorrow/the week after next.
After winning the prize she became famous overnight.
After an hour I went home (= when an hour had passed).
It’s ten after seven in the morning (= 7.10 a.m.).

senses.definition: next to and following somebody/something in order or importance

examples.en: Your name comes after mine in the list.
He's the tallest, after Richard.
After you (= Please go first).
After you with the charger (= Can I have it next?).

senses.definition: behind somebody when they have left; following somebody

examples.en: Shut the door after you.
I'm always having to clean up after the children (= clean the place after they have left it dirty and untidy).
He ran after her with the book.
She was left staring after him.

senses.definition: in contrast to something

examples.en: It was pleasantly cool in the house after the sticky heat outside.

senses.definition: as a result of or because of something that has happened

examples.en: I'll never forgive them after what they did.

senses.definition: despite something; although something has happened

examples.en: I can't believe she'd do that, not after all I've done for her.

senses.definition: used to show that something happens many times or continuously

examples.en: day after day of hot weather
I've told you time after time not to do that.

senses.definition: trying to find or catch somebody/something

examples.en: The police are after them.
He's after a job at our place.

senses.definition: about somebody/something

examples.en: She asked after you (= how you were).

senses.definition: in the style of somebody/something; following the example of somebody/something

examples.en: a painting after Goya
We named the baby Ena after her grandmother.

senses.definition: happening or done later than the time or event mentioned

examples.en: after-hours drinking (= after closing time)
an after-school club
after-dinner mints

senses.definition: despite what has been said or expected

examples.en: So you made it after all!

senses.definition: used when you are explaining something, or giving a reason

examples.en: He should have paid. He suggested it, after all.

senses.definition: to be going to do something soon; to be intending to do something soon
to have just done something
at a time later than something; when something has finished

examples.en: I'll call you after I've spoken to them.

senses.definition: later in time; afterwards

examples.en: That was in 1996. Soon after, I heard that he'd died.
I could come next week, or the week after.
And they all lived happily ever after.

senses.definition: following; later

examples.en: in after years

senses.definition: the situation that exists as a result of an important (and usually unpleasant) event, especially a war, an accident, etc.

examples.en: A lot of rebuilding took place in the aftermath of the war.
the assassination of the prime minister and its immediate aftermath

The president visited the region in the immediate aftermath of the disaster.

senses.definition: the period of time from 12 o'clock in the middle of the day until about 6 o’clock in the evening

examples.en: this/yesterday/tomorrow afternoon
In the afternoon, they went shopping.
Where were you on the afternoon of May 21?
Heavy snow arrived during the afternoon.
She studies art two afternoons a week.
Come over on Sunday afternoon.
The baby always has an afternoon nap.
Are you ready for this afternoon's meeting?
The activities are split into morning and afternoon sessions.

variants.html: (North American English usually afterward)

senses.definition: at a later time; after an event that has already been mentioned

examples.en: Afterwards she was sorry for what she'd said.
Let's go out now and eat afterwards.
Shortly afterwards he met her again.
He went to dinner at a restaurant, and soon afterwards, he fell ill.

senses.definition: one more time; on another occasion

examples.en: This must never happen again.
Try again—it takes practice.
Can we start again, please?
Could you say it again, please?
When will I see you again?
This author again proves to be a superb storyteller.
I've told you again and again (= many times) not to do that.
I'll have to write it all over again (= again from the beginning).
She tried over and over again (= many times) to get it right.
He has yet again (= as has happened many times before) shown that he cannot be trusted.
Once again (= as had happened several times before), the train was late.

senses.definition: showing that somebody/something is in the same place or state that they were in originally

examples.en: We're very happy to be here together again.
He was glad to be home again.
You'll soon feel well again.
She spends two hours a day getting to work and back again.

senses.definition: added to an amount that is already there

examples.en: The cost is about half as much again as it was two years ago.
I'd like the same again (= the same amount or the same thing).

senses.definition: used to show that a comment or fact is connected with what you have just said

examples.en: And again, we must think of the cost.

senses.definition: used to introduce a fact or an opinion that contrasts with what you have just said

examples.en: We might buy it but then again we might not.

senses.definition: used when you ask somebody to tell you something or repeat something that you think they have told you already

examples.en: What was the name again?

senses.definition: from time to time; occasionally

examples.en: Every now and again she checked to see if he was still asleep.

senses.definition: used to ask somebody to serve you the same drink as before

examples.en: Same again, please!

idioms.word: time after time | time and (time) again

senses.definition: often; on many or all occasions

examples.en: You will get a perfect result time after time if you follow these instructions.
Time and again, the girls have shown how strong and determined they can be.

senses.definition: opposing or disagreeing with somebody/something

examples.en: the fight against terrorism
We're playing against the league champions next week.
We were rowing against the current.
That's against the law.
Employees can't be forced to join a union against their will.

She is against seeing (= does not want to see) him.
I'd advise you against doing that.

senses.definition: not to the advantage or favour of somebody/something

examples.en: The evidence is against him.
Her age is against her.

senses.definition: close to, touching or hitting somebody/something

examples.en: Put the piano there, against the wall.
The rain beat against the windows.

senses.definition: in order to prevent something from happening or to reduce the damage caused by something

examples.en: an injection against rabies
They took precautions against fire.
Are we insured against theft?
He gritted his teeth against the pain.

senses.definition: with something in the background, as a contrast

examples.en: His red clothes stood out clearly against the snow.

senses.definition: used when you are comparing two things

examples.en: You must weigh the benefits against the cost.

What's the rate of exchange against the dollar?

senses.definition: if you include money or costs against an amount that is owed, you use it to reduce the amount

examples.en: The accountant said I could offset all my travel costs against tax.

senses.definition: if you borrow money against property that you own, you use the value of the property as a guarantee that you will repay the money

examples.en: They had borrowed a lot of money against the value of the house.

senses.definition: in contrast with something

examples.en: They got 27 per cent of the vote as against 32 per cent at the last election.

idioms.word: the cards/odds are stacked against you

senses.definition: you are unlikely to succeed because the conditions are not good for you
the number of years that a person has lived or a thing has existed

examples.en: You're the same age as my brother.
ways of calculating the age of the earth
to reach retirement age
He left school at the age of 18.
He started playing the piano at an early age.
At your age I had already started work.
Children can start school from the age of four.
children between the ages of 5 and 10
The children range in age from 5 to 10.
The children's ages range from 5 to 10.
Children over the age of 12 must pay full fare.
The film is unsuitable for children below 12 years of age.
Young people of all ages go there to meet.
She needs more friends of her own age.
All ages admitted.
He was tall for his age (= taller than you would expect, considering his age).
She was beginning to feel her age (= feel that she was getting old).
The show appeals to all age ranges.
There’s a big age gap between them (= a big difference in their ages).

senses.definition: a very long time

examples.en: It'll probably take ages to find a parking space.
I waited for ages.
Carlos left ages ago.
It's been an age since we've seen them.

senses.definition: a particular period of a person’s life

examples.en: in middle/old age

senses.definition: a particular period of history

examples.en: the nuclear age

a study of fashion through the ages

senses.definition: the state of being old

examples.en: The jacket was showing signs of age.

Wine improves with age.
the wisdom that comes with age

senses.definition: a length of time that is a division of an epoch
to behave in a way that is suitable for somebody of your age and not as though you were much younger

examples.en: Isn’t it time you started acting your age?

senses.definition: when a person comes of age, they reach the age when they have an adult’s legal rights and responsibilities

examples.en: The money will go to the children when they come of age.

senses.definition: if something comes of age, it reaches the stage of development at which people accept and value it

examples.en: It was the year that concern for the environment really came of age.

senses.definition: to realize that you are getting old, especially compared with people you are with who are younger than you
a great age

examples.en: She finally learned to drive at the grand old age of 70.

senses.definition: now, in the modern world

examples.en: Slavery continues to exist, even in this day and age.
Why dress so formally in this day and age?

senses.definition: to seem as old as you really are and not younger or older

examples.en: She doesn’t look her age; I thought she was ten years younger.

idioms.word: of advanced years | somebody’s advanced age

senses.definition: used in polite expressions to describe somebody as ‘very old’

examples.en: He was a man of advanced years.

senses.definition: if you talk about a person being of a certain age, you mean that they are no longer young but not yet old

examples.en: The show appeals to an audience of a certain age.

senses.definition: an age that is considered to be very old

examples.en: He lived to the ripe old age of 91.

senses.definition: not legally old enough to do a particular thing

examples.en: It is illegal to sell vapes to children who are under age.

senses.definition: the action or result of

examples.en: breakage

senses.definition: a state or condition of

examples.en: bondage

senses.definition: a set or group of

examples.en: baggage

senses.definition: an amount of

examples.en: mileage

senses.definition: the cost of

examples.en: postage

senses.definition: a place where

examples.en: anchorage

senses.definition: to become older

examples.en: As he aged, his memory got worse.
The population is aging (= more people are living longer).
This film hasn't aged well at all (= it seems old-fashioned now).

senses.definition: to look, feel or seem older; to make somebody/something look, feel or seem older

examples.en: My mother has really aged since she became ill.
The shock has aged her.
Exposure to the sun ages the skin.
These photos have been artificially aged.

senses.definition: to develop in taste over a period of time; to allow something to do this

examples.en: The cheese is left to age for at least a year.
The wine is aged in oak casks.
This wine has not aged well.

senses.definition: of the age of

examples.en: They have two children aged six and nine.
volunteers aged between 25 and 40
Children have the opportunity to meet similarly aged children.

senses.definition: very old

examples.en: my aged aunt
People caring for an aged relative need support.
I’m not sure if my aged car can make it up that hill.

senses.definition: very old people

examples.en: services for the sick and the aged

senses.definition: a business or an organization that provides a particular service especially when representing other businesses or organizations

examples.en: She works for an advertising agency.
He managed to find a job through an agency.

senses.definition: a government department that provides a particular service

examples.en: law enforcement agencies
Some laboratories are operated by government agencies.

senses.definition: as a result of the action of somebody/something

examples.en: He obtained his position through the agency of an old friend.

senses.definition: a list of items to be discussed at a meeting

examples.en: We have a very full agenda of issues to discuss.

senses.definition: a plan of things to be done, or problems to be addressed

examples.en: In our company, quality is high on the agenda.

Education is now at the top of the government's agenda (= most important).
Cost-cutting is top of the agenda for the next quarter.

The college needs to draw up an agenda for change.

senses.definition: the intention behind what somebody says or does, that is often secret

examples.en: The artist is letting his own agenda affect what was meant to be a community project.

senses.definition: a person whose job is to act for, or manage the affairs of, other people in business, politics, etc.

examples.en: Our agent in New York deals with all US sales.

an insurance agent

senses.definition: a person whose job is to arrange work for an actor, musician, sports player, etc. or to find somebody who will publish a writer’s work

examples.en: a theatrical/literary agent

senses.definition: a person who works secretly to obtain information for a government or other organization

examples.en: He was arrested by federal agents.
an enemy/undercover agent
CIA/FBI agents

senses.definition: a person or thing that has an important effect on a situation

examples.en: The charity has been an agent for social change.

senses.definition: a chemical or a substance that produces an effect or a change or is used for a particular purpose

examples.en: chemical/biological agents
cleaning/oxidizing agents

senses.definition: the person or thing that does an action (expressed as the subject of an active verb, or in a ‘by’ phrase with a passive verb)
feelings of anger and hate that may result in threatening or violent behaviour

examples.en: Video games have been blamed for causing aggression.
Nowadays our aggression is channelled into sports.

senses.definition: a violent attack or threats by one person against another person or by one country against another country

examples.en: unprovoked military aggression

senses.definition: angry, and behaving in a threatening way; ready to attack

examples.en: Seals have been known to exhibit aggressive behaviour towards swimmers.
They became increasingly aggressive as the evening wore on.
There's no need to get aggressive.
She warned that her dog was aggressive towards strangers.

senses.definition: determined and acting with force in order to succeed

examples.en: a very aggressive advertising campaign
We need to get more aggressive in our approach.

senses.definition: developing quickly and difficult to treat

examples.en: Doctors diagnosed her with a rare and aggressive cancer, which was feared to be incurable.

senses.definition: using all possible treatment options in order to extend somebody’s life

examples.en: Nicholas was diagnosed with the rare disease in November and has undergone aggressive treatments since then.

senses.definition: used in expressions of time with the simple past tense to show how far in the past something happened

examples.en: two weeks/months/years ago

She was here just a minute ago.
a short/long time ago
How long ago did you buy it?
It was on TV not (so) long ago.
Scientists think there was water on Mars a long time ago.
He stopped working some time ago (= quite a long time ago).
They're getting married? It's not that long ago (= it's only a short time ago) that they met!

senses.definition: to have the same opinion as somebody; to say that you have the same opinion

examples.en: When he said that, I had to agree.
‘That's true’, she agreed.
I totally agree with you!
You can't expect them to agree on everything.
He agreed with them about the need for change.
Many experts agree wholeheartedly with this statement.
I tend to agree with her political views.
All parties agree (that) urgent action is required.
We agreed (that) the proposal was a good one.
‘It's terrible.’ ‘I couldn't agree more!’ (= I completely agree)

senses.definition: to approve of something because you think it is morally right

examples.en: I don't agree with hitting children as a punishment.

She agreed (that) I could go early.

She agreed to let me go early.

senses.definition: to decide with somebody else to do something or to have something

examples.en: Can we agree on a date?

They met at the agreed time.
Can we agree a price?
We agreed to meet on Thursday.
We couldn't agree what to do.
They left at ten, as agreed.

senses.definition: to officially accept a plan, request, etc.

examples.en: The company agreed a deal worth $100 million.
Next year's budget has been agreed.
We arranged to meet a few days later and agree terms.

senses.definition: to be the same as something

examples.en: The figures do not agree.
Your account of the accident does not agree with hers.

senses.definition: to match a word or phrase in number, gender or person

examples.en: In ‘Tom likes jazz’, the singular verb ‘likes’ agrees with the subject ‘Tom’.

examples.cf: arrangement with somebody to do something

senses.definition: a group of things that are organized or placed in a particular order or position; the act of placing things in a particular order

senses.definition: a piece of music that has been changed, for example for another instrument to play

senses.definition: a group or collection of things or people, often one that is large or impressive

senses.definition: a way of organizing and storing related data in a computer memory
a set of numbers, signs or values arranged in rows and columns

senses.definition: to arrange soldiers in a position from which they are ready to attack

examples.en: the hostile forces arrayed against them

senses.definition: if the police arrest somebody, the person is taken to a police station and kept there because the police believe they may be guilty of a crime

She was arrested and charged with arson.

senses.definition: to stop a process or a development

senses.definition: to make somebody notice something and pay attention to it

senses.definition: if somebody arrests, their heart stops beating

senses.definition: the act of arresting somebody

senses.definition: an act of something stopping or being interrupted

senses.definition: an act of coming or being brought to a place

senses.definition: the part of an airport that you go through when you arrive on a plane

senses.definition: the time when a new technology or idea is introduced

senses.definition: to happen or to come, especially when you have been waiting for it

senses.definition: somebody has become successful

senses.definition: a thin stick with a sharp point at one end, which is shot from a bow

senses.definition: a mark or sign like an arrow (➞), used to show direction or position

examples.en: Follow the arrows.

senses.definition: the use of the imagination to express ideas or feelings, particularly in painting, drawing or sculpture

examples.en: modern/contemporary art
an art critic/historian/lover

stolen works of art

American art

senses.definition: examples of objects such as paintings, drawings or sculptures

examples.en: an art gallery/exhibition

senses.definition: the skill of creating objects such as paintings and drawings, especially when you study it

an art teacher/student/college/class

senses.definition: art, music, theatre, literature, etc. when you think of them as a group

senses.definition: a type of visual or performing art

examples.en: an exhibition of Peruvian arts and crafts

senses.definition: the subjects you can study at school or university that are not sciences, such as languages, history or literature

senses.definition: an ability or a skill that you can develop with training and practice

idioms.word: get something down to a fine art

senses.definition: to learn to do something well and efficiently

examples.en: I spend so much time travelling that I've got packing down to a fine art.

senses.definition: used to mean ‘you are’, when talking to one person
a first name for boys, sometimes short for Arthur
(1910-56) a US musician considered one of the greatest jazz piano players. He was nearly blind all his life.
a piece of writing about a particular subject in a newspaper or magazine, on a website, etc.

examples.en: to read/write/publish an article

senses.definition: a separate item in an agreement or a contract

senses.definition: a particular item or separate thing, especially one of a set

senses.definition: the words a and an (the indefinite article) or the (the definite article)

senses.definition: to express or explain your thoughts or feelings clearly in words

senses.definition: to speak, pronounce or play something in a clear way

senses.definition: to be related to something so that together the two parts form a whole

senses.definition: to be joined to something else by a joint, so that movement is possible; to join something in this way

examples.en: bones that articulate with others
a robot with articulated limbs

senses.definition: good at expressing ideas or feelings clearly in words

examples.en: He was unusually articulate for a ten-year-old.

senses.definition: clearly expressed or pronounced

senses.definition: made or produced to copy something natural; not real

examples.en: an artificial limb/flower/sweetener/fertilizer

senses.definition: created by people; not happening naturally

senses.definition: not what it appears to be

examples.en: artificial emotion

senses.definition: a person who creates works of art, especially paintings or drawings

examples.en: an exhibition of work by contemporary British artists
a graphic artist
a make-up artist

)

senses.definition: a person who is a professional singer, dancer, actor, etc.

senses.definition: showing a natural skill or pleasure in art, especially being able to paint or draw well

senses.definition: done with skill and imagination; attractive or beautiful

examples.en: an artistic arrangement of dried flowers

senses.definition: the freedom of artists or writers to change facts in order to make a story, painting, etc. more interesting or beautiful
pictures and photographs prepared for books, magazines, etc.

senses.definition: a work of art, especially one in a museum; works of art as a group

examples.en: 30 original artworks have gone missing from the museum.
a collection of artwork from different cultures

senses.definition: used to describe somebody/something appearing to be somebody/something else

senses.definition: used to describe the fact that somebody/something has a particular job or function

examples.en: She works as a courier.

senses.definition: used when you are comparing two people or things, or two situations

examples.en: You're as tall as your father.

senses.definition: used to emphasize an amount

senses.definition: to behave in a way that shows that you are sorry for something that you have done

They are able to offer attractive career opportunities to graduates.
