senses.definition: to say or believe that something is the result of a particular thing

examples.en: She attributes her success to hard work and a little luck.
The power failure was attributed to the recent storms and high winds.

senses.definition: to say or believe that somebody is responsible for doing something, especially for saying, writing or painting something

examples.en: This play is usually attributed to Shakespeare.
a quote that has often been falsely attributed to George Patton

senses.definition: to regard a quality or feature as belonging to somebody/something

examples.en: The committee refused to attribute blame without further information.
Ancient peoples attributed magical properties to the stones.
The goals commonly attributed to management are status, power, salary and security.

senses.definition: a quality or feature of somebody/something

examples.en: Patience is one of the most important attributes in a teacher.
The most basic attribute of all animals is consciousness.

senses.definition: a public sale in which things are sold to the person who offers the most money for them

examples.en: an auction of paintings
A classic Rolls-Royce fetched (= was sold for) £25 000 at auction.
The house is up for auction (= will be sold at an auction).
an internet auction site

senses.definition: to sell something at an auction

examples.en: The costumes from the movie are to be auctioned for charity.

senses.definition: the group of people who have gathered to watch or listen to something (a play, concert, somebody speaking, etc.)

examples.en: The audience was/were clapping for 10 minutes.
The debate was televised in front of a live audience.
an audience of 10 000
Audience members voted on their favorite presentations.
We encourage audience participation during our show.

senses.definition: a number of people or a particular group of people who watch, read, or listen to the same thing

examples.en: TV/television/cinema/movie audiences
His book reached an even wider audience when it was made into a movie.
This book will appeal to a broad audience.
She has generated a massive online audience since uploading her first clip three years ago.
The target audience for this advertisement was mainly teenagers.
An audience of millions watched the wedding on TV.
Most companies now have their own websites which address mass audiences.
They aim to make art accessible to the widest possible audience.

senses.definition: a formal meeting with an important person

examples.en: an audience with the Pope

senses.definition: connected with sound that is recorded

examples.en: audio and video recordings/files/clips
The audio quality was poor.

senses.definition: recorded sound

examples.en: digital audio

senses.definition: connected with hearing or sound

examples.en: audiovisual

senses.definition: an official examination of business and financial records to see that they are true and correct

examples.en: an annual audit
a tax audit
preparing the accounts for audit

senses.definition: an official examination of the quality or standard of something

examples.en: an environmental audit

senses.definition: to officially examine the financial accounts of a company

examples.en: We have just had our accounts audited.
The National Audit office is responsible for auditing the accounts of a wide range of bodies.

senses.definition: to officially examine the quality or standard of something

examples.en: We have decided to audit our recruitment policy to ensure it is as fair and inclusive as possible.

senses.definition: to attend a course at college or university but without taking any exams or receiving credit

examples.en: She audited classes at the University of California.

senses.definition: impressive, making you feel respect

examples.en: an august group of statesmen
He had dared to challenge the views of an august body of imperial historians.

senses.definition: the 8th month of the year, between July and September

examples.en: She was born in August.
The meeting is on the fifth of August/August the fifth.
The meeting is on August fifth.
We went to Japan last August.
I arrived at the end of August.
last August's election
It was a hot August afternoon.

senses.definition: the sister of your father or mother; the wife of your uncle or aunt

examples.en: Aunt Alice
My aunt lives in Canada.
Great Aunt Emily
Mathilde lives with her aunt and uncle on a small farm.

senses.definition: used by children, with a first name, to address a woman who is a friend of their parents
known to be real and what somebody claims it is and not a copy

examples.en: I don't know if the painting is authentic.

senses.definition: true and accurate

examples.en: an authentic account of life in the desert
the authentic voice of young black Americans

senses.definition: made to be exactly the same as the original

examples.en: an authentic model of the ancient town
Take a trip on an authentic Spanish galleon to the famous Papagayo beach.

senses.definition: a person who writes books or the person who wrote a particular book

examples.en: Who is your favourite author?
He is the author of three books on art.
best-selling author Paul Theroux
the lead author of the report
the author of a novel/study/article
Who's the author?
According to report author Matt Blaze, the technique requires no special skill.
Really quick author's note: This is the last chapter of the story.
The film is based on a novel written by a French author.
The report's authors point to a recent study of American college students.

senses.definition: the person who creates or starts something, especially a plan or an idea

examples.en: As the author of the proposal I cannot agree with you.
He is the author of a plan to bring peace to the region.

senses.definition: to be the author of a book, report, etc.
the power to give orders to people

examples.en: in a position of authority
to undermine/challenge somebody's authority
She now has authority over the people who used to be her bosses.
The law states that parents exercise authority over their children.
Nothing will be done because no one in authority (= who has a position of power) takes the matter seriously.
adult authority figures such as parents and teachers

senses.definition: the power or right to do something

examples.en: Some experts think the agency may have exceeded its authority.
The government has the authority to regulate the economy.
The Constitution gives Congress the authority to decide whether to fund military action.
We have the authority to search this building.

senses.definition: official permission to do something

examples.en: He took the car without authority.
It was done without the principal's authority.
We acted under the authority of the UN.

senses.definition: the people or an organization who have the power to make decisions or who have a particular area of responsibility in a country or region

examples.en: I have to report this to the authorities.
The health authorities are investigating the problem.
planning/police/immigration authorities
Aviation authorities say traffic will grow 20 per cent a year.
German authorities arrested the author of the computer virus.

senses.definition: the power to influence people because they respect your knowledge or official position

examples.en: He spoke with authority on the topic.
the moral authority to run the country
She bore an air of authority.

senses.definition: a person with special knowledge

examples.en: She's an authority on criminal law.

senses.definition: to be able to believe something because you trust the person who gave you the information

examples.en: I have it on good authority that he is going to be promoted.

variants.html: (British English also authorise)

senses.definition: to give official permission for something, or for somebody to do something

examples.en: I can authorize payments up to £5 000.
I have authorized him to act for me while I am away.
The soldiers were authorized to shoot at will.

senses.definition: a car

examples.en: the auto industry

senses.definition: of or by yourself

examples.en: autobiography

senses.definition: by itself without a person to operate it

examples.en: automatic

senses.definition: relating to cars

examples.en: autocross

senses.definition: having controls that work without needing a person to operate them

examples.en: automatic doors
a fully automatic driverless train
automatic transmission (= in a car, etc.)
an automatic rifle (= one that continues to fire as long as the trigger is pressed)
My camera has manual and automatic functions.

senses.definition: done or happening without thinking

examples.en: Breathing is an automatic function of the body.
My reaction was automatic.

senses.definition: always happening as a result of a particular action or situation

examples.en: A fine for this offence is automatic.
Promotion was almost automatic after two or three years.

senses.definition: a gun that can fire bullets continuously as long as the trigger is pressed
a vehicle with a system of gears that operates without direct action from the driver
without needing a person to operate controls

examples.en: The heating switches off automatically.

senses.definition: without thinking

examples.en: I turned left automatically without thinking.

senses.definition: in a way that always happens as a result of a particular action or situation

examples.en: You will automatically get free dental treatment if you are under 18.

senses.definition: the freedom for a country, a region or an organization to govern itself independently

examples.en: a campaign in Wales for greater autonomy

senses.definition: the ability to act and make decisions without being controlled by anyone else

examples.en: giving individuals greater autonomy in their own lives

variants.html: (North American English usually fall)

senses.definition: the season of the year between summer and winter, when leaves change colour and the weather becomes colder

examples.en: in the autumn of 2024
He is in the autumn of his career.
in early/late autumn
the autumn term (= for example at a school or college in Britain)
autumn leaves/colours
It's been a very mild autumn this year.
a crisp/chilly/wet/cool autumn
their autumn collection of dresses (= designed to be worn in autumn)
Demand always rises during the autumn and winter months.

senses.definition: the fact that something is possible to get, buy or find

examples.en: the availability of cheap flights
This offer is subject to availability.

senses.definition: the fact that somebody is free to see or talk to people

examples.en: Check her availability before you schedule the meeting.

senses.definition: that you can get, buy or find

examples.en: available resources/data
Most available evidence suggests that home-schooled children are getting a good education.
Further details are available on request.
We'll send you a copy as soon as it becomes available.
We have plenty of office space available.
The document is now commercially available in electronic form.
readily/widely/freely/publicly available
Tickets are currently available at reduced prices from the festival office.
This data is still available for download on the company's website.
When will the information be made available to the public?

senses.definition: free to see or talk to people

examples.en: Will she be available this afternoon?
She is in a meeting at present, but I will let you know as soon as she becomes available.
They'll be available to help every day next week.
The director was not available for comment.

senses.definition: not currently involved in a sexual or romantic relationship

examples.en: the pool of available singles
Do you think he's available?

senses.definition: calculated by adding several amounts together, finding a total, and dividing the total by the number of amounts

examples.en: The average age of participants was 52 years.
an average rate/cost/price
an average annual income/wage/salary
Average daily summer temperatures are about 20°C .
Average earnings are around £35 000 per annum.
The school has an average class size of 24 students.
at an average speed of 100 miles per hour

senses.definition: typical or normal

examples.en: babies of below average birth weight
£20 for dinner is about average.
The average person can't afford to fly first class everywhere.
40 hours is a fairly average working week for most people.

senses.definition: ordinary; not especially good

examples.en: I was just an average sort of student.
The route is for walkers of average ability.
The quality has been pretty average (= not very good).

senses.definition: the result of adding several amounts together, finding a total, and dividing the total by the number of amounts

examples.en: The average of 4, 5 and 9 is 6.
Parents spend an average of $220 a year on toys.
Prices rose by an average of 10 percent over the decade.
If I get an A on this essay, that will bring my average (= average mark/grade) up to a B+.
Class sizes in the school are below the national average.
We will deliver growth in the economy that is higher than the OECD average this year.
They had higher mortality rates from accidents compared with the national average.
Children here score well above the city average on math and reading tests.

senses.definition: a level that is usual

examples.en: Temperatures are above average for the time of year.
400 people a year die of this disease on average.

senses.definition: the principle that one thing will happen as often as another if you try enough times

examples.en: Keep applying and by the law of averages you'll get a job sooner or later.

senses.definition: to be equal to a particular amount as an average

examples.en: Economic growth is expected to average 2% next year.
Drivers in London can expect to average about 12 miles per hour (= to have that as their average speed).
The women averaged 41 points per game.
He has averaged 15 goals over the past two seasons.
Wages here average less than three dollars an hour.

senses.definition: to calculate the average of something

examples.en: Earnings are averaged over the whole period.
The items were summed and averaged by the number of items.

senses.definition: to prevent something bad from happening

examples.en: to avoid conflict/confrontation
We must find a way to avoid similar problems in future.
They narrowly avoided defeat.
The name was changed to avoid confusion with another firm.
The accident could have been avoided.
Efforts are being made to avoid war at all costs.
They built a wall to avoid soil being washed away.

senses.definition: to keep away from somebody/something; to try not to do something

examples.en: He's been avoiding me all week.
She kept avoiding my eyes (= avoided looking at me).
By staying at home he manages to avoid all contact with strangers.
Certain foods should be avoided during pregnancy.
I left early to avoid the rush hour.
He tried to avoid paying his taxes and was taken to court.

senses.definition: to prevent yourself from hitting something

examples.en: The car swerved to avoid a cat.

senses.definition: to try very hard not to meet somebody, do something, etc.

examples.en: She's been avoiding me like the plague since the party last Saturday.
I hate office parties—I avoid them like the plague.

idioms.word: to fall into/avoid the trap of doing something

senses.definition: to do/avoid doing something that is a mistake but that seems at first to be a good idea

examples.en: Parents often fall into the trap of trying to do everything for their children.
The movie avoids the trap of spending too much time explaining things.

senses.definition: to wait for somebody/something

examples.en: He is in custody awaiting trial.
Her latest novel is eagerly awaited.

senses.definition: to be going to happen to somebody

examples.en: A warm welcome awaits all our guests.
Who knows what dangers may await us?

senses.definition: a prize such as money, etc. for something that somebody has done

examples.en: He was nominated for the best actor award.
the UK's most prestigious literary award
the Housing Design Award
The mayor will present the awards.
to win/accept an award for something
He received numerous awards for excellence in teaching.
She was recently honoured with a lifetime achievement award.
The winners of the awards are picked by the network's viewers.
an awards ceremony

senses.definition: an increase in the amount of money somebody earns

examples.en: an annual pay award
The union is unhappy with this year's pay award.

senses.definition: an amount of money given as an official payment or grant to somebody

examples.en: an award of £600 000 in libel damages
The judge has the power to make damages awards.
Students on diploma courses could apply for a discretionary award from their local authority.

senses.definition: the official decision to give something to somebody

examples.en: Satisfactory completion of the course will lead to the award of the Diploma of Social Work.
The court must specify the different elements in its award of compensation.

senses.definition: to make an official decision to give something to somebody as a payment, prize, contract, etc.

examples.en: Knowing why and how corporations award contracts is vitally important.
The judges awarded equal points to both finalists.
The judges awarded both finalists equal points.
He was awarded damages of £50 000.
He was posthumously awarded the Victoria Cross.
The referee awarded a penalty against them.

senses.definition: knowing or realizing something

examples.en: As you're aware, this is not a new problem.
As far as I'm aware, nobody has done anything about it.
acutely/painfully/keenly (= very) aware
He was well aware of the problem.
She slipped away without him being aware of it.
They suddenly became aware of people looking at them.
Everybody should be made aware of the risks involved.
We're just making the public aware of the issue.
I am fully aware of the fact that change needs time.
I don't think people are really aware of just how much it costs.
Were you aware that something was wrong?
I was aware that she was trembling.

senses.definition: interested in and knowing about something, and thinking it is important

examples.en: Young people are very environmentally aware.
People are becoming more politically and socially aware.
Food manufacturers are dealing with increasingly aware consumers.

senses.definition: knowing something; knowing that something exists and is important

examples.en: an awareness of the importance of eating a healthy diet
There was an almost complete lack of awareness of the issues involved.
to raise/heighten/increase public awareness of something
a greater/a growing/an increasing awareness of something
a marketing campaign to increase brand awareness
There seems to be a general awareness that this is not the solution.

senses.definition: interest in and concern about a particular situation or area of interest

examples.en: environmental awareness
Energy Awareness Week
the emergence of a new social awareness among young people
The group is trying to raise public awareness about homelessness.

senses.definition: to or at a distance from somebody/something in space or time

examples.en: The beach is a mile away.
Christmas is still months away.
The president was kept well away from the demonstrators.
The station is a few minutes' walk away from here.
The main landfill site was moved further away from the city.

senses.definition: to a different place or in a different direction

examples.en: Go away!
Put your toys away.
The bright light made her look away.

senses.definition: not present

examples.en: There were ten children away yesterday.
Sorry, he's away.
She was away from work for a week.

senses.definition: used after verbs to say that something is done continuously or with a lot of energy

examples.en: She was still writing away furiously when the bell went.
They were soon chatting away like old friends.

senses.definition: until disappearing completely

examples.en: The water boiled away.
The music faded away.

senses.definition: at the opponent’s ground or stadium

examples.en: Chelsea are playing away this Saturday.

senses.definition: used to say that you would like to be rid of somebody/something

examples.en: Away with all these rules and regulations!

senses.definition: to help somebody have a fresh, lively state of mind again

examples.en: A brisk walk should blow the cobwebs away.

senses.definition: to dance for the whole evening or night
by a very great amount

examples.en: She's far and away the best player.

senses.definition: immediately; without delay

examples.en: I want it sent right away.
I told him right off what I thought of him.

senses.definition: immediately; without delay

examples.en: I'll do it straight away.

senses.definition: played or scored at the opponent’s ground or stadium

examples.en: an away match/game
an away win
an away goal

senses.definition: very bad or unpleasant

examples.en: That's an awful colour.
‘They didn't even offer to pay.’ ‘Oh that's awful.’
I feel awful about forgetting her birthday.
to look/feel awful (= to look/feel ill)
There's an awful smell in here.
The awful thing is, it was my fault.
It sounds awful to say it, but the war was exciting.
The weather conditions were just awful.
It's awful, isn't it?
The weather last summer was awful.

senses.definition: that shocks people very much

examples.en: the awful horrors of war
It was only later that we learned the awful truth.

senses.definition: used to emphasize something, especially that there is a large amount or too much of something

examples.en: It's going to cost an awful lot of money.
There's not an awful lot of room.
I feel an awful lot better than I did yesterday.
I had an awful job persuading him to come (= it was very difficult).

senses.definition: very; extremely

examples.en: Clint is awful smart.

senses.definition: making you feel embarrassed

examples.en: There was an awkward silence.
I felt awkward because they obviously wanted to be alone.

senses.definition: difficult to deal with

examples.en: Don't ask awkward questions.
You've put me in an awkward position.
an awkward customer (= a person who is difficult to deal with)
Please don't be awkward about letting him come.
It makes things awkward for everyone when you behave like that.

senses.definition: not convenient

examples.en: Have I come at an awkward time?
That's a bit awkward for me—could we make it earlier?

senses.definition: difficult or dangerous because of its shape or design

examples.en: This box is very awkward for one person to carry.
This tool will reach into awkward corners, such as under kitchen units.

senses.definition: not moving in an easy way; not comfortable

examples.en: He tried to dance, but he was too clumsy and awkward.
I must have slept in an awkward position—I'm aching all over.
